transcription.text: I'm talking about how ENS, the Catherium name service, is taking Ethereum to the rest of
the Internet.
Okay, so our name obviously is the Ethereum name service.
I want to explain what this means because this is going to, I think, explain a lot.
So how is it a name service?
Naming services are things that people don't think about very much.
It's kind of something in the background.
And a lot of people actually misunderstand how they work.
So naming services, a naming service is just a lookup system.
That's it.
It doesn't do anything else.
You provide a name, it provides with information.
That's it.
People over complicate this.
Your computer might then do something with that information, but that is separate from
the naming service.
So for example, with ENS, a lot of people think that if you're sending to an ENS address,
that ENS sends the transaction on to them for you or something like that.
Nope, all ENS does is it tells the wallet which address to send to and then the wallet
sends the transaction.
That all happens in the background.
The user doesn't see that.
That's what's really happening.
So why do we have naming services?
Obviously computer identifiers.
What makes sense for computers?
What makes sense for humans?
Don't mix.
The Internet already has a naming system, domain name system.
So even for blockchain things, why don't we just use DNS?
A lot of people that I've talked to you haven't even thought about this, DNS could provide
naming for cryptocurrency addresses.
It's a naming service.
It can provide naming for anything.
So why don't we?
Well, because DNS launched in 1985, it's fairly insecure, it's fairly centralized, and so
it kind of doesn't go along with the values of the blockchain world.
But I just want to point out that DNS could do all these things for the blockchain world
if we wanted to use it for that.
So ENS is a naming service, right?
It has names, owners of names, as records that can store any information.
If you have a name, you can write and look it up.
You can do something with that information.
But this is key.
It can store any information.
It's not just for Ethereum.
So why is it the Ethereum name service?
It's not because it's naming service only for the Ethereum ecosystem.
It's because it's built on Ethereum.
This is common confusion.
If you're thinking, "Hmm, if it's confusing, why don't you rebrand?"
Well, we're thinking about it.
But right now, this is very important to understand.
So just, it's called this right because the logic and records are stored on the Ethereum
blockchain, but it can store information relevant to anything, right?
So Ethereum is just like the infrastructure in the background that it happens to run
on, but that doesn't restrict the types of information you can store on it, right?
You could store phone numbers.
You could store your home address.
You could store a Bitcoin address.
You could store anything.
It's a common misconception that it can't.
We have this right on our website.
It's been there all along.
So why do we use Ethereum as our back end?
It's a good question, right?
There's other blockchain out there.
If even if we wanted to have a blockchain naming service built on a blockchain, here's
some advantages.
Ethereum has a very high security built into it.
If you were making our own chain or something like that, we have to bootstrap security.
It would be low security.
It would be probably less decentralized.
Ethereum, we can build on Ethereum.
It has high security and decentralized right out of the back.
We can benefit from all the ecosystem infrastructure.
It's like MetaMask and Fure.
I mean, tons of services that we benefit from.
Right away, we don't have to reinvent those things.
We benefit from standards.
So all DOT ETH names are actually ERC721 compliant.
So a DOT ETH name is going to plug into NFT markets.
That's a benefit that we have from being on Ethereum.
Ethereum ability, so you could have things like conditioned ownership of name or something
that's time-locked for a certain period of time.
Also, interaction with other contracts on Ethereum.
This is extremely powerful.
The fact that ENS can do this, if we were building on our own chain or on a different
chain, we wouldn't benefit from the Ethereum ecosystem in this way.
We think this is why Ethereum is the best place to be building a blockchain-based naming
system.
So to sum up, ENS uses Ethereum to serve the internet, including and beyond the Ethereum
ecosystem.
As a result, our goal is to make ENS and therefore Ethereum a basic piece of internet infrastructure
used widely by people whether they are part of the blockchain community or not.
And the rest of this presentation is about how we are doing that.
So of course, we do support the Ethereum ecosystem.
I don't want to give the impression that we're moving beyond the Ethereum ecosystem.
That's still a core thing that we do.
That's kind of our bread and butter.
But ENS does much more than that.
And many people don't know that ENS does much more than that.
So I'm going to be talking about more in detail all the non-directly Ethereum-related things
that we support.
Okay.
So IPFS, the Interplanetary File System.
IPFS is a peer-to-peer decentralized file system, file sharing protocol.
ENS is a decentralized naming service.
So together, they are the decentralized web.
We actually have a partnership with Protocol Labs, a building out infrastructure on this
and promoting this kind of duo of protocols.
We already have native support for this pair of protocols in Opera.
And Brave says they are also working on adding this.
So we are getting native browser support.
But if you're using a browser that doesn't have native support, we benefit from MetaMask.
MetaMask supports this.
So if you are using Chrome, Firefox, Edge, Brave, or even the Tor browser, which we'll
be talking about here in a second.
You automatically support this decentralized web.
And you can try it right now, actually.
So we recommend this is a great starting place, almonnet.eth.
You have to put a slash at the end if you're doing it in MetaMask, so it will recognize
it.
If you type this in, it will load up.
And this is a directory of websites, decentralized websites.
So this is a great place to start.
This works right now.
We also have a project called ETH DNS, which is a bridge between DNS and DNS plus IPFS.
There's much more that could be said about this.
We actually just published a blog post yesterday with more details.
So go to our medium, check it out.
But for users, the bottom line is we own ETH.link on DNS.
We've set up a special server there so that if there is a decentralized website and you
don't have MetaMask or you're not using Opera, you can still access it.
Just add .link to the end of it and it will resolve like a normal website.
So this is a great way if you want to put your DAPs front end on IPFS and make it accessible
via ENS, but you still want normal people to be able to access it.
Use this.
So Tor.union addresses.
So Tor.union websites have been around for a while.
They have a naming problem.
They have the same naming problem that normal websites would have that they have an address
to find the server.
They need a naming system, but they don't trust DNS because DNS is insecure.
It's centralized and Tor is all about security.
Right now, if you wanted to go to a .union website in the Tor browser, you have to go
to something like this.
This is very non-user friendly.
ENS solves this problem.
So ENS is obviously decentralized secure naming solution that works today.
And we've added support for .union addresses in our records.
And you can use this in the Tor browser if you have MetaMask.
So the Tor browser is Firefox based.
If you add in the, put in the add on MetaMask and you type in a .east name that has a Tor.union
address in its records, it will resolve to that Tor.union website.
So this works today.
You can try it right now.
So we actually set up 10 of these addresses to kind of show off this functionality.
So like Duck.gov.
I could set up correctly, you could start using it, and then I could, if I really wanted to
be bad, I could then change it to a different address, and then you might not know that
I changed it so you're going to an, I could go to a phishing website or something like
that.
I can't do that.
So actually, nobody owns these addresses, but they still work.
That's something you can't do with DNS, by the way.
Somebody always controls the DNS records.
Ahouwe is actually just launched this with text records in our manager.
You can now, to put it to any DNS name, you can put like an email address, website, a
link to an avatar, a description, anything you want.
Like if you're trying to sell a name, or if you just want people to know who you are,
or however you want to use it, this works right now.
And we're going to be adding the ability to put custom text records very soon.
This is what it looks like in our manager.
Other cryptocurrencies.
You heard, what I've heard about this yesterday, if you saw Nick Johnson, our lead developer's
presentation.
But we just added multi-coin support on Mainnet.
It works right now, at least on the DNS protocol level.
And basically, it works the same way as with Ethereum addresses.
You just store like the Bitcoin address, or EOS address, or something like that, in the
record.
And then the wallet, if there's someone types in the name, can grab that address, and then
the wallet sends the transaction, right?
Some people are like, well, how does that work?
Because it's on a different chain.
Well, it's only, it's just the words being stored.
So for any cryptocurrency, any arbitrary cryptocurrency this works for.
And we have a wallet that's actually just about ready to launch this.
They said that their beta version of this would be launching either today or the next
couple days, and then in a normal production mobile app by the end of the month.
Decent Wallet.
This is a hardware and mobile wallet based out of South Korea.
This is their website, Decent Wallet.com.
They support a bunch of different currencies.
And they were really great to kind of partner with us, to kind of build this new functionality.
And actually, I want to show a video of this.
Ah, darn it.
Okay, we're not on a different computer.
So we had a video of this working, a demo on Mainnet.
You can imagine how it works exactly the same way as the Ethereum addresses, but with Bitcoin
addresses in this video.
Sorry, we had to switch computers.
Okay.
But we have commitments from more than just Decent Wallet.
We actually have commitments from seven other wallets to add this functionality either in
the next couple weeks or months.
They are on board with this Coinbase wallet, Trust Wallet, I am token, Haven, My Crypto
Portis and Opera.
And we are also in discussions with other wallets.
So we really like this to be the standard for all wallet naming.
And if you are involved in another multi-coin wallet, please let us know.
We'd love to work with you on this.
And this new functionality was actually funded by a grant from Binance X.
So thank you to Binance X.
We really appreciate the support.
Okay.
And we are also working on DNS namespace integration.
So this is really important to understand.
A lot of people think that ENS is dot ETH.
It's not.
Like banish that idea from your name.
Banish the idea from your mind.
Okay.
ENS is not dot ETH names.
ENS is a naming system infrastructure.
Dot ETH is just one top level domain that happens to work on it.
But any name could run on the ENS infrastructure.
These completely separate things that you need to have separately in your mind.
So this distinction also holds true for DNS.
So there's like the DNS infrastructure.
And then there's the DNS namespace completely different.
The name space could remain the same even if the infrastructure changed.
Okay.
And so ENS could support in principle any name.
And this is exactly what we're trying to do.
So we've actually devised a system so that if you own a name on DNS, only the owner of
that name can claim use of that name on ENS.
Not with dot ETH, but with the same top level domain.
So for example, Ethereum dot org, the EF could, if they used our system, which is coming out
here very soon, could have a DNS record and an ENS record for Ethereum dot org, not Ethereum
dot ETH.
And we use something called DNS stack to do this.
I'm not going to explain this in detail, but it's a pretty clever system that Nick Johnson
came up with here.
And we actually, this actually works right now for dot XYZ.
So like Argent Wallet uses this.
The dot XYZ was kind of our test case.
And we're now confident in this system.
We're going to be rolling this out to all other DNS that can enable DNS top level domains,
which is all the ones you've heard of.
We also have some special use cases for these other top level domains, dot lux, dot cred,
dot art.
Oh yeah, so some people said, well, if you're going to integrate the DNS namespace, why
do we need dot ETH?
Well, because dot ETH is native to ENS, it has special properties.
So so DNS names will still be subject to DNS controls because ownership goes only one
direction.
Whoever owns the DNS version of it owns the ENS version of it.
But because dot ETH names are native to ENS, they have their they have individual ownership
in or not subject to the same controls.
Some people ask about our relationship with ICANN.
I'll just say a few words.
It's friendly.
We've gone to their conferences.
We've given presentations.
Almost everybody is very open and receptive to ENS.
In fact, people approach us to, hey, we want to work together.
So we think there's a lot of potential to working together.
Also, this is a key thing to know.
ICANN is not monolithic.
Some people will say this is what ICANN thinks or ICANN does.
ICANN is a lot of different people who think different things.
They don't always agree.
So keep that in mind.
All right, I'm going to skip this running low on time.
New DNS are our type.
We are working on getting a new record type in the DNS system for Ethereum addresses.
So we can standardize our process for claiming DNS names on ENS.
But this could be used beyond ENS.
Just want you to be aware of that.
And we're also working on getting ETH dot ARPA.
Dot ARPA domains are used for basic internet infrastructure.
And we are working on getting this for use for the whole Ethereum community.
This would be another kind of a semi-official link of Ethereum to the legacy internet.
And then we're also working on traditional DNS records.
Our public resolver actually supports this right now.
But we have a project going with dot cred dot cred as a DNS top level domain.
They have agreed to work with us to build a system to use ENS and IPFS to host all of
their traditional DNS records for their whole namespace, which would be an incredible first
step towards having ENS abused for that use case.
So we are very excited about this.
It's amazing they've agreed to do this with us.
We've talked to lots of other top level domains who are kind of interested.
But they tend to be very conservative.
So they're willing to experiment with us on this.
And we're very happy about that.
So that's it.
Thank you very much.
There are some important links.
And we have one minute if anybody wants to ask a question.
Yeah, so just run up to the mic here and we have time for maybe one or two.
I can also talk afterwards.
We have some of our developers here as well.
What happens if DNS want to add dot eth names?
Are they going to?
I mean, in the DNS root, it's currently reserved as a three-letter country code for Ethiopia.
Although they are not using any three-letter country codes.
They're just like reserved in defense.
And I've talked to people who say that they're actually probably not going to give them to
the countries.
So at some point we might be able to get dot eth as a GTLD, but that may or may not happen.
Actually, that's something to add to that.
So it's probably unclear that ENS would ever be able to get the dot eth TLD.
So the main issue is that for you to be an eye can approve TLD, you must abide by something
called the Uniform Domain Dispute Resolution Policy, or UDRP, which basically says things
like copyrights and trademarks are enforced.
And we're not really going for that.
Maybe technologically you can't do that without ease.
Yeah, yeah.
So I imagine that's probably just going to be like just a non-starter.
So currently I'm counting the idea that you could have some eye can approve TLDs that do
enforce trademarks and then some that don't.
So they have a very strict requirement that anything within their route does enforce trademarks.
Right.
We will see how that goes.
Right.
Yes.
Last question.
About the hardware wallet integration, does the hardware wallet actually display the dot
eth name when you confirm the what wallet integration with hardware wallets that are using ENS?
Hardware.
Yes.
So on the device it displays.
I don't know if it's on the device.
Good question.
But in their mobile app that uses their hardware wallet.
Okay, I was just going to ask because it's very hard for hardware devices to authenticate

So I was curious how you saw it.
Oh, yeah.
